questions.text: Which TCA intermediate is used in haem synthesis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Succinyl-CoA The first step of haem synthesis uses succinyl-CoA which is intermediate to TCA. Fumarate, Alpha-ketoglutarate and malate (4C) are also intermediates of TCA. But they are not used for heme synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is required for the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B 6 The first and also the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis is catalyzed by ALA synthase Conversion of Succinyl-CoA to α-Amino-β-ketoadipate requires pyridoxal phosphate (B6) . This is the first step of the synthesis of heme that takes place in the α-Amino-β-ketoadipate is rapidly decarboxylated to δ-aminolevulinate. This is why vitamin B 6 deficiency leads to sideroblastic anemia . Copper is also necessary for the synthesis of hemoglobin as Cu is a constituent of ALA synthase.

questions.text: Acquired porphyria is due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lead poisoning Porphyria can be either inherited or acquired. Causes of acquired porphyria: Lead poisoning Alcoholism Hepatitis C infection Lead-induced acquired porphyria is known as Plumboporphyria .

questions.text: All of the following are hepatic porphyrias, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protoporphyria X-linked protoporphyria, Congenital erythropoietic porphyria & Protoporphyria are erythropoietic porphyrias . Type of porphyria Erythropoietic porphyrias Acute hepatic porphyrias Clinical features: ● Cutaneous symptoms appear in early childhood ● Variable extra-hepatic gastrointestinal manifestations ● Neurological-psychiatric symptoms ● Cardiovascular symptoms Complications: ● Cholestatic liver cirrhosis and progressive hepatic failure ● HCC

questions.text: A newborn develops jaundice (yellow skin and yellow scleras) that requires laboratory evaluation. Which of the following porphyrin derivatives is conjugated, reacts directly, and is a major component of bile?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilirubin diglucuronide Jaundice is the yellowish color of the skin and sclera caused by the increased level of bilirubin in the blood. Causes of Jaundice are: Increased production of bilirubin due to hemolytic anemia or malaria, Decrease in the excretion of bilirubin due to liver damage, Bile duct obstruction In newborns, jaundice is normal (physiologic) after 24 hours of birth due to the immaturity of the liver Only excess jaundice is evaluated, depending on the age of the infant. High levels of bilirubin in serum (indirect bilirubin) point toward hemolysis from maternofetal blood group incompatibility. While high levels of bilirubin diglucuronide (one of several conjugated bilirubins tested as direct bilirubin) suggest liver/gastrointestinal disease. Chromatographic fractionation of serum bilirubin: α bilirubin unconjugated bilirubin β bilirubin bilirubin monoglucuronide γ bilirubin bilirubin diglucuronide δ bilirubin albumin-bound conjugated bilirubin

questions.text: Bilirubin and urobilinogen are products of heme catabolism which occur mainly in the liver and intestine. This processing is hindered in some disease states causing Hyperbilirubinemia. A condition of Hyperbilirubinemia with the absence of urobilinogen in urine is seen in:

options.label: D
options.text: Obstruction of the common bile duct

questions.correct_answer: D. Obstruction of the common bile duct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obstruction of the common bile duct Urobilinogen is formed from the degradation of bile pigments by bacterial action. In case of obstruction to bile flow, as happens in cholelithiasis or any kind of biliary obstruction, There will be no urobilinogen in urine. So, No formation of stercobilinogen, and the patient passes clay-colored stools. Option analysis: Hemolysis produces a lot of urobilinogen which is excreted in urine → option A and C are excluded. In hepatocellular jaundice , urobilinogen can be normal or reduced. The question specifically uses the word "absent" → option B is also excluded.

questions.text: There are various forms of porphyrins depending on different side chains. Which of the following Porphyrins is present in normal erythrocyte hemoglobin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protoporphyrin III The side chain groups in porphyrins may be arranged in four different structural configurations (I to IV). Haem is iron-containing protoporphyrin III and formed by the action of ferrochelatase as: The only type I and type III series are found in nature and the porphyrins of the type III series are not only more abundant but are also physiologically important in humans.

questions.text: Mark the false statement among the given options related to heme:

options.label: A
options.text: Glycine is required in 1st step of heme synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Heme oxygenase produces CO2 , Fe3+ & water

options.label: C
options.text: Pyridoxal phosphate is required for the synthesis of δ-amino levulinic acid

options.label: D
options.text: Cu is a constituent of ALA synthase

questions.correct_answer: B. Heme oxygenase produces CO2 , Fe3+ & water
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heme oxygenase produces CO 2 , Fe 3+ & water Haem catabolism Heme oxygenase is involved in haem catabolism and catalyzes the first step of haem conversion to biliverdin It uses oxygen & it produces CO, Fe 3+ & water. But it does not produce CO 2 . Haem Synthesis In the first step of haem synthesis, Glycine amino acid is required Glycine condenses with succinyl CoA to form 6-amino levulinate which serves as a precursor for haem synthesis. Copper is necessary for the synthesis of hemoglobin because Cu is a constituent of ALA synthase, needed for heme synthesis. Pyridoxal phosphate is required for the synthesis of δ-amino levulinic acid, the precursor for heme. Extra Information on haem catabolism Senescent RBCs are destroyed in the reticuloendothelial System (RES) releasing hemoglobin The globin part enters the amino acid pool Heme iron is usually oxidized to ferric iron forming hemin Hemin is the substrate of the microsomal Heme Oxygenase system.

questions.text: Lead poisoning is a buildup of lead in the body over a period of months to years. Lead ingestion exposure is of special concern for infants and toddlers. Symptoms of lead poisoning may include developmental delays, learning disabilities and low IQ, abdominal pain, constipation, neurologic changes, and irritability. Which statement is not true regarding lead poisoning?

options.label: B
options.text: Lead inhibits ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase enzymes

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduced levels of zinc protoporphyrin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduced levels of zinc protoporphyrin Lead poisoning results in elevated levels of zinc protoporphyrin. Lead inhibits ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase, both enzymes involved in the synthesis of heme, and therefore causes a decrease in heme synthesis. Further, high levels of lead impair iron utilization. This results in increased use of zinc (instead of iron) as a substrate for chelation to protoporphyrin IX by ferrochelatase. Consequently, patients with lead poisoning may present with anemia and elevated levels of zinc protoporphyrin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is CORRECT? a. Hemoglobin is a homotetramer b. The taut conformation of hemoglobin releases oxygen c. Oxidation of iron of hemoglobin produces met hemoglobin d. By oxygenation of hemoglobin, iron is in the ferrous state Select the correct answer from the given below option:

options.label: B
options.text: If b, c, and d are correct

options.label: C
options.text: If a, b, and d are correct

options.label: D
options.text: If all four (a, b, c, & d) are correct

questions.correct_answer: B. If b, c, and d are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If b, c, and d are correct Hemoglobin is a tetramer composed of two types of subunits designated α and β, with stoichiometry α 2 β 2 . Hemoglobin exists in two forms: Taut (tense) form (T) Relaxed form (R). Various factors favor the taut form: Low pH high CO 2 high 2, 3 BPG at the level of the tissues The taut form has low oxygen affinity than the R state and releases oxygen in the tissues. Oxidation of Hb means oxidation of metal-iron (from the ferrous to the ferric state) in the heme portion of hemoglobin making metHb. MetHb cannot bind oxygen. Oxygenation of Hb means oxygen is attached to Hb. The iron atom is still in the ferrous state.

questions.text: All of the following will cause a shift to the right of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in pH In the oxygen dissociation curve (ODC) of Hb, the partial pressure of oxygen is plotted on the X-axis, and the percentage of hemoglobin saturated with oxygen is plotted on the Y-axis. We get a sigmoidal curve for hemoglobin. A shift of the oxygen dissociation curve to the right refers to the increased unloading of oxygen. Imagine a person doing exercise in a warm room. Raised CO2, temperature, 2,3-DPG, and decreased pH causes shift of ODC to right.

ALA to PBG Lead is found in both exterior and interior wall paints. questions.text: A case of child patient presents with Hypertrichosis was present on the face and back of the patient along with blisters on the face, nose, and hands. HMB was found abundantly in the teeth and bones and in the plasma, bone marrow, feces, red blood cells, and urine as confirmed by laboratory tests. Image below shows the presence of erythrodontia. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency Uroporphyrinogen III synthase cyclizes and isomerizes hydroxymethylbilane to produce the asymmetric uroporphyrinogen III. A deficiency in this enzyme results in congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP). Uroporphyrinogen III undergoes decarboxylation of its acetate groups by uroporphyrinogen III decarboxylase (UROD), generating coproporphyrinogen III. A deficiency in this enzyme results in porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). These three reactions occur in the cytosol.
